H0.text: What is the name of the strong fibrous tissue that joins one bone to another at a joint. Tendon

H1.text: What is the name of the strong fibrous tissue that joins one bone to another at a joint. Cartilage

H2.text: What is the name of the strong fibrous tissue that joins one bone to another at a joint. Sinew

H3.text: What is the name of the strong fibrous tissue that joins one bone to another at a joint. Ligament

A4.text: A tendon or sinew is a tough band of dense fibrous connective tissue that connects muscle to bone.

A5.text: Ligaments connect bone to bone, while tendons connect muscle to bone.

A6.text: The whole tendon is enclosed by a fascia.

A7.text: In tendons, the fibrils then assemble further to form fascicles, which are about 10 mm in length with a diameter of 50–300 μm, and finally into a tendon fibre with a diameter of 100–500 μm.
